Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned how to approach chemistry problem-solving from a completely different depth and perspective. While the Oxtoby textbook presents problems that are of AP Chemistry level, Professor Wang challenges us to go above a surface understanding of each topic, such as thermodynamics or kinetics, and combine different concepts together when solving his problem sets or midterm questions. I gained a better understanding of inorganic and physical chemistry, and can now definitively say that I enjoy chemistry and STEM and will want to major in something related.

I learned SO MUCH chemistry this semester at an unbelievable pace. We covered general chemistry, but studied it at a "comprehensive," deeper level than students in the other general chemistry course. I also learned how to take exams with a time crunch.
I learned a lot about physical chemistry, and I also learned that I really needed to rely on my friends for help since a lot of the material was really hard.
This class teaches kinetics, acid base, equilibrium, and materials basics.
Loved it, learned a lot about chemistry.
A LOT of chemistry. I'm a sophomore and my suitemate is in PChem... he said a lot of what we did is at the level of what is done in PChem 1.
Learned about gases, kinetics, acids/bases, equilibrium, electrochemistry, thermochemistry, and spectroscopy. Very physics/mathematics-based course.

I have been exposed to such a wide breadth of material and concepts, spanning beyond GenChem into organic and physical chemistry. I have a new understanding for many areas of research within chemistry. Beyond chemistry itself, I have also learned a lot about challenging myself and persevering through a difficult course.

From this course, I developed a lot more of my quantitative reasoning skills as well as learned a lot of physical chemistry concepts. This class also trains you to take a question that you never seen before and work with it to come up with an answer and apply all the different concepts you learned to different real life scenarios.

We learned about gases, thermodynamics and entropy, acids and bases, electrochemistry, nuclear chemistry, and a little bit of spectroscopy. The course was very math-heavy, in contrast to CHEM 163, so we were pushed to think about how we could apply different equations and concepts to solve problems. I think that this meant that this course required us to use a conceptual understanding of the topics in a different way from how Prof. Mayer's did.
Chem 167 taught its students how to bridge gaps between different topics of chemistry to see how they could work together.
I learned how to solve quantitative chemistry problems and also gained a good understanding of the underlying concepts behind the questions.
This class goes FAR BEYOND traditional AP chemistry. I learned a lot about new topics including kinetics, thermo, etc. (our TA described it as "basically PChem").
I gained essential quantitative chemistry reasoning skills.  Like Chem 163, I think the ability to think about chemistry problems was the most important skill I learned.
I learned chemistry concerning gas laws, electrochemistry, nuclear chemistry, equilibrium, and various other topics.
Math and chemistry come together
I learned a lot of in depth concepts about physical chemistry.

I learned many chemistry skills, such as calculating various thermodynamic and kinetic properties of chemical reactions. I also learned how to think critically about chemistry, using calculus and algebra to manipulate equations to fit new situations.

I developed skills in Applied math in the realms of Chemistry, particularly deriving many formulas I have used in my past Chemistry education. This course covered a wide variety of chemistry topics, from Thermochemistry to Electrochemistry to Kinetics to Equilibrium and beyond.

I learned a lot of chemistry knowledge including gas laws, thermodynamics, equilibrium, etc. I also learned the skill of answering hard questions in a short amount of time and strengthening my critical thinking skills.
I gained a better understanding of physical chemistry
I feel like I have a better understanding of gases, thermodynamics, kinetics, and equilibrium. I also believe that I have developed stronger quantitative reasoning skills.
Learned more in-depth about acids and bases,  equilibrium, thermochem, phase transitions.
I think my problem solving skills improved a lot from taking this class; I also think that I've gained a relatively solid foundation in general chemistry.
Taking this course, I developed some skills and insights to solve problems related to class concepts. I learned about Acid-Base chemistry, electrochem, state functions, gas laws, and a lot more.
Acid-base chemistry, nuclear chemistry, chemical equilibria, gas laws, chemical kinetics, etc.
I not only developed advance fFreshman chemistry knowledge, but I also learned how to adapt my studying habits to suit the course and myself.

I learned a lot  in this class. It is like an introductory physical chemistry class. It covered acid-base, equilibrium, kinetics, electrochem, and more. It was very very difficult though. I learned how to approach a really difficult class as well.

This course required me to learn advanced problem solving and critical thinking skills to solve both homework and exam questions. You really have to understand the material in order to apply that knowledge in new ways. In terms of the material, this class is an extension of many of the key topics of AP Chemistry, but covered in a more practical, in-depth and comprehensive way.

Although CHEM 167 was an extremely challenging class, it was well worth it. We learned about different phases and their properties, thermodynamics, chemical kinetics, electrochemistry, nuclear chemistry, spectroscopy, and a bit about solid materials. Beyond the academic material, I learned how to approach different problems and got a lot of good tips on how to study in general from my TA.

By taking this course, I gained knowledge about foundational concepts of physical chemistry, acid-base theory, kinetics, chemical equilibriums, thermodynamics, electrochemistry, spectroscopy, and nuclear reactions. No practical skills were learned (since lab takes care of that), but the topics went over in CHEM 167 were interesting. Although there is significant overlap between CHEM 165 and 167, I believe CHEM 167 had a more in-depth and interesting investigation into chemical concepts.

I learned an extensive amount about the physical nature and interactions of chemicals in different states, the thermodynamic properties of materials, and about quantifying solubility, equilibrium, and rate reactions, among other things.
I feel that by the end of the semester I understood most of the material in the course. Where the first semester was about materials, this semester was more about what happens when they interact.
This course was a very in depth overview of Chemistry basics. Topics such as thermodynamics and equilibrium were covered in much detail.
I learned more about topics which fall under the umbrella of general chemistry. It covered a wide range of topics in an indepth manner.

The course was designed in a way such that lecture and textbook material complemented each other, which I greatly enjoyed, since usually one will render the other obsolete and useless. I do wish that there were more practice problems (ungraded) like practice midterms released by the professor, since only one TA wrote his own extra practice problems, and they usually were not parallel with midterm content.

Strengths: The TAs were a tremendous resource for this course--they held weekly office hours for help with psets or to clarify topics from lecture, and the professor also had office hours if you needed to ask any questions.
Weaknesses: this is not really a weakness, but something that students often struggled with was the pace of the course. We covered at least one new chapter every week, and you had to keep up with the material because you would be tested immediately. It was nice that we had a week between the last chapter covered and an upcoming exam, but that meant that most people weren't really engaged during that week and would have to review it well before the next exam.

It was often unreasonably complicated or hard. The concepts themselves weren't often terribly difficult, but they were often explained too quickly and in unclear ways. The saplings in general were also just far too long. Although they were generally helpful to an extent, they'd always take many hours and I gained nothing from the extra problems except wasting time. The psets also were often confusing or very difficult, I'd only be able to do them after spending hours with friends, and going to several TF sessions. Although psets should definitely be challenging, and this course as a whole should be hard, at a certain point there was no way I could figure out answers by myself even when I wanted to and tried, so I'd just be relying on other people to show me what to do, which didn't lead to any actual understanding.
This course teaches a wide variety of topics, which is a positive, but these topics are taught too quickly.
Lectures were a little rough at the beginning, but got better with time.

It's very very comprehensive. A bit extra, I think... people stuck with it and learned a lot, but it does have a high barrier of entry insofar as you have to put a lot of work into it. The term-time exams are a lot of material for the time given, which means that score is affected by ability to do the problems quickly. I wish that hadn't been the case as much. So maybe making the exams shorter would be better.

This is something that is a personal pet peeve, but the TFs did often show you exactly what to do on the problem sets in section. This comes at everyone's expense... the people who watch them do it get the answers right but don't learn and suffer on exams, while the people who try on their own end up losing points and being way below average because so many people are getting full or nearly full points. So please let us do the problem sets on our own since this forces us to choose between losing options.
Strengths include mathematical basis and understanding of how formulas and concepts are derived

One strength of this course is the curve. Although the class is very challenging, Hailang Wang is very generous with the curve. He is aware that he is really challenging us on the exams, and he equates an A with raw exam scores close to an 80. Without this curve, the majority of the students would be failing the course. 

One weakness of the course is the lack of organization in material and within lecture. We go topic from topic without any real transitions between material, and sometimes its more difficult to see the big picture of the course because we spend so much time on nitty-gritty derivations and tangents into the professor's research.

The course was strong because it covered so much material that we learned a lot, while having a strong support system to prevent us from falling through. The organization of the course could be improved because sometimes the material felt a bit scattered, but when you take a step back you realize every piece of the puzzle fits together in the end to tie all the different topics together in a meaningful way.

Especially at the beginning of the course, it felt like Prof. Wang didn't have a good sense of what we knew and what we didn't know as intro chemistry students. A lot of us felt that he vastly overestimated what we knew when he wrote the first test, and a lot of the early lectures were difficult for many of us to follow. Over the course of the semester, however, I definitely think that Prof. Wang got a lot better about judging the level that he should write the lectures at, and they became a lot easier to follow and learn from. 

I found this course really challenging overall, and I think that in a way I'm glad of that because it pushed me to try my hardest and seek out help when I needed it, but there were also a few things about it that I thought made it tough but didn't need to. One problem that I ran into whenever I was preparing for exams was that I felt like we didn't have adequate materials with which to prepare. Prof. Wang always suggested that we study the problem sets, and I think that helped, but the problem sets alone didn't really provide us with enough study material, especially since they were each 4 or 5 questions each. Prof. Wang wrote a lot of challenging questions on the exams, and though I wouldn't say that his questions were necessarily unfair,  it could still be really hard to know how to solve them when we hadn't been able to work with similar problems in the problem sets, just because the problem sets could only capture so many of the types of questions that he would write. Also, towards the end of the course, we covered material in spectroscopy that didn't really align with the textbook, and I had trouble finding good materials to study it at a similar level to how Prof. Wang was teaching it. I think it would be helpful if Prof. Wang could have written us a few practice tests or supplemental practice problems to prep for exams, or perhaps pointed out particular textbook problems that he thought could be helpful (the textbook problems were often very different/easier than the types of questions he wrote, so it wasn't very helpful to try and work on them on our own). 

We had one really dedicated teaching fellow, Zach, who really went out of his way to help us out. He always held office hours and review sessions and tried to write us some practice problems, and we definitely appreciated that. I thought that Yizhou was a good teaching fellow too, and he always helped me out with my problem sets when I asked him about them. Having good teaching fellows definitely made a big difference for a tough course like this.

Chem 167 was a very challenging course that covered a very wide range of topics. Although each individual topic was interesting, the course tended to be so overwhelming that the material could not be properly internalized. By slowing down the course a bit, or not adding so many varied topics, it might help students better learn the material and better understand the connection between different topics.

The course was very interesting and the material was explained clearly. The pacing of the class seemed challenging but not overwhelmingly fast, and I liked that exam questions required us to adapt our knowledge to new types of problems. One weakness was that the exams were long for the time we were given, so they seemed to test quick thinking and didn't always reflect how much we actually understood without rushing.

The workload of this class is extremely high. Prof Wang gives challenging psets in addition to the Sapling homework, and together, the class has around 6 hours of homework a week. The course material is difficult and can be really hard to grasp from Prof Wang's lectures alone. It is definitely a large time commitment (sometimes unnecessarily so), but go to peer tutoring and section if you can (especially if you have Zach Carter as a TF). Though hard, it is a really fulfilling course and you do learn an extreme amount of material that will supposedly make future chem courses much easier.
Sometimes disorganized. Professor was very knowledgeable though.

This course is great to challenge yourself in regards to thinking quantitatively about chemistry.  In the first part of this course, the professor did a lot of derivations very quickly on the board, and it would have been better if he went slower through that material since most students in the class had not taken physics yet in college.  He could have more clearly defined the variables he was using. As the semester progressed he did get better at defining variables and going slower such that most students could understand the derivations he was doing.  I think it would be beneficial if he could allow for more questions from students during lecture.

The course was well taught, and I feel I did learn a lot. The pacing was especially jarring in the beginning, but became better as the year continued. I feel that the course was heavily shaped by the outside help as well though, and without it, I do not know how the class would have felt.
Very organized

The strength was my TF Zach. He really went above and beyond with his discussion sections and office hours. Also, I think Professor Wang was a very organized teacher. The course could be improved by making the tests not during the 50 minutes of class. The time constraint made them way too difficult to finish.
Strengths of the course include the challenging content that forces you to think in new ways. Weaknesses include the fast pace and at times the organization.

The course was definitely very difficult content and while the explanations were engaging and clear (for the most part), the supportive resources and materials could have been more expansive. The power points, for example, did not have many of the equations that were taught in class. This presented problems, particularly when I could not read all of the expressions on the board. Access to copies of derivations or even to equations sheets would have been invaluable.

The strength is the interesting material, the teaching, and the TAs. One weakness is the time pressure on tests, which made it difficult to fully master concepts because there wasn't enough time. But I think that this still served to improve time management skills.

The course was challenging. The strengths of the course were my TA, the weaknesses were unorganized lectures. Professor very open to feedback, and got significantly better as course went on. Not enough time to take exams. If want to challenge us with level of tests, must offer more time for students to have time to think. Hard for students with testing anxiety and who are not fast test takers.
hard as hell
Professor Wang is a terrific lecturer and was extremely engaging. I also enjoyed section, but I would have preferred if TAs had more structure in section meetings.

A strength of this class is that it's a challenge. I feel more confident going into higher level courses. However, this class has more weaknesses than strengths. There is an absurd amount of work that goes on outside the classroom. This is not what I take issue with; I'm here to learn things, to understand scientific concepts and master the material, and I'm willing to do an absurd amount of work to achieve that. My issue with the amount of work in this course is related to the KIND of work that we were doing on a week-by-week basis. I feel strongly that having an electronic Sapling Learning problem set in addition to one written by the professor is unnecessary, and the Sapling is consistently busywork. Far from ideal. I suggest eliminating Sapling.

A strength of the course was the problem sets. Although difficult, they were helpful to really learn the material. A weakness is that sometimes the lecture does not match what is material is on the problem sets. Often I felt like the material we needed to know was not clear.

Strengths: Resources (TAs, peer tutors, etc.), organization
Weaknesses: Very mathematically based, less conceptual knowledge tested
In the beginning the lectures were a bit weak, and I think the class would be more enjoyable and easier if the lectures were more engaging.

The material was interesting. However, I do no think that lecture was very helpful in teaching the concepts. The class required a lot of time outside of class to learn the material. There were also not many resources, no practice exams or practice questions, which made it very difficult to study.

I think that a strength of this course is its difficulty level. It's not fun sometimes, but it challenges you to think critically about every situation. The course material is very advanced, that is another strength, you are being taught high-level topics in a first-year class, that too is also a strength, it's not the average general chemistry course. Lecture was good, the professor explained the topics reasonably well. With that said, the course is very fast paced, and the material very challenging. 
But the biggest weakness was the uneven quality of the TA's. One was outstanding, and worked very hard to make sure everyone understood the material. The other two were not as good, one example being they used section to go over homework rather than reinforce material learned in lecture. They were also less capable of answering questions and teaching the material.
The class is very comprehensive and covers a lot of material in detail. It can be hard to learn much in lecture, but TA office hours (especially Zach's) are super helpful

Strengths: The order of the material makes sense, and the lectures pretty much follow the textbook with some extra information, so it makes studying the material much easier. The test turnaround was also extremely, abnormally fast, so it was nice to know our grade so soon.

Weaknesses: We usually ran out of time with the exams, so I felt that our knowledge wasn't tested as well.

A strength (and possibly a weakness) of this course is the amount of material covered in the semester: it is a lot of material, but not all of it was tested on (how could you test on every detail of every topic?). Another strength is the lecture, and how Professor Wang would start and end lectures on time, and how he did not require close reading of the textbook: although everything he said in class wouldn't be on the exams, 1) it is easy to pick out the important parts, and 2) it was interesting nonetheless. For example, we learned how a car battery and a lithium ion battery worked. One weakness, however, is the inconsistency among the TF's: one TF would lead discussion sections by covering material learned in lecture, while the other two TF's would only go over the PSETs and exams.
Way to much Sapling online homework on top of the written homework.

This course covers an incredible amount of material, and it does a great job getting you to think outside the box to solve tough problems in chemistry. The breadth and intensity of this course are both incredible, and while this means you will learn to think critically in chemistry, the course can also be very challenging and fast-paced. Many important concepts are covered in lectures but the course moves so fast that it can be easy to misunderstand them or never grasp the reasons why certain concepts where even taught. The course content is expansive, and it makes the class interesting but at the same time makes each unit feel disparate and incongruous.
The stuff in this course sort of connects, but the connections could be better emphasized.

The course was difficult at first since it was the professor's first year. This meant Professor Wang had somewhat unreasonable expectations. Having said that, one of the greatest strengths was the implementation of feedback from the students. Towards the end of the semester, course material was still very challenging but not unreasonable.

The course was very challenging but there were the adequate resources available to help students. One of the major weaknesses of the course was the fact that the level of helpfulness of the teaching fellows ranged so greatly that it almost felt unfair if you didn't have the TF most students considered "the best"

Definitely take this class if you are interested in learning much more about inorganic chemistry. Definitely don't take this class if you are concerned about your grade, because the midterms and problem sets will take you down (our class averages on the midterms were around 50%, 70%, and 80%). But, it is worth it if you are willing to put in the time and effort to practice and really understand the material beyond a purely computational mindset.

Yes. People will tell you to take the other general chemistry class because it is easier, but I found this class extremely engaging, despite how challenging it was. It definitely takes up a lot of your time, so you have to be willing to put in the effort. But if you put in the effort, I think that what you get corresponds with what you get. The professors and TAs know how hard this class is, so they provide you with resources and end up curving the class generously.

No, I didn't find it incredibly interesting and I don't think I got more out of it than I would've the lower chemistry course because I didn't understand a lot. By making the upper class so hard, it also penalized students decided to stay because we're going to end up with lower grades after working harder than the students who dropped.
I would not recommend this course unless it is required for your major
Yes, but only if they enjoy chemistry.

Yes, but only if he is very interested in continuing with chem. Like, physical chem and a chem degree. If you're just pre-med or going for a major like G&G or something else that requires a little chem, this will be a lot of work, and a lot of what you learn you'll probably never use again. I was one of the only non-freshmen in the class, and I didn't take 165. I didn't feel like it was impossible to keep up, but it is worth noting that when a lot of the other people in the class are taking BIOL 103, Psych and the Good Life, underwater basketweaving, etc., and meanwhile you're taking an upper level Chem E class, CS, etc., the competition can be tough--everyone else has a lot more time to study that you do.
Do not take gen chem at Yale. Take freshman orgo instead.
Course is definitely challenging and pushes you to think hard and go beyond. Would recommend if you want a good intro to more physical chemistry (lots of physics-type concepts).

I would only recommend this course to students who truly want an academic challenge. You can receive the same credit in GenChem and have a much easier time with the material and workload. This course is alright for someone who is willing to spend a lot of time studying the material and going to review sessions to gain an understanding that you can't get just from lecture.

Yes I would recommend this course to any student in the sciences/engineering because it is a great foundation for your skills in chemistry, as well as its applications in biology or physics. It is quite the challenge but they do compensate for that with the support system and curves that are reasonably generous.

I'm not really sure. Overall, I'm glad that I took this course instead of CHEM 165 because I'm glad that I challenged myself and I think that helped me learn the material more effectively. However, now that I've spent a year at Yale, I'm pretty sure that I'm not going to major in any of the natural sciences and that means that I didn't need to take this course at all. I think that if you're going to take chemistry, and you know you need it, then taking a course like this will be more rewarding than taking a course you know will be easier -- at the same time, you should know going in that it's going to be a lot of work, and you should be prepared to work hard to understand the material. Sometimes it felt like even when I was working really hard, it was still really challenging for me to be successful on the exams. With that in mind, this course may not be the best choice for you if you know that you have one or two really other really hard courses in the same semester.

I would recommend this course if it took a step back from intensity and pressure on the students. I feel as though many times the work was overwhelming and too much to handle for those who had a weaker background in chemistry.
Yes, I would. It was an interesting and well-structured course that provided good fundamentals for general chemistry.
Yes, I would recommend this class to another student. The workload is very high, but if you're interested in chemistry, you will learn SO MUCH and it's more interesting than gen chem.

I would recommend this course to another student who enjoys science and thinking quantitatively.  You really need to enjoy learning the material for this class to be worth the amount of time you will need to put into it.  But if you enjoy learning the material this can be an extremely rewarding class.

If you want a challenge then take this course. If you don't want to invest mass amounts of time into chemistry, or don't really find it interesting do not take it. You need to have at least some moderate level of interest in chemistry. Without it, you will struggle in this course, and it will not feel worth it all.
If you want a challenge
I would recommend this course to someone who wants to study chemistry in depth.

I would recommend this course only if you are prepared for a very challenging chemistry course. If you merely need to com[lete the intro chem requirement I would take an easier course instead. The math and critical thinking skills that you must use are fairly difficult, but completing the course is rewarding if you are ready to put the time and effort in. Just be aware that the time and effort required are significant, and that you will likely feel overwhelmed at times. Going to TA office hours and the peer tutors is absolutely essential. Although lecture is decently well taught, it is difficult to grasp the material without the help of the TAs. We had extraordinary TAs this year which made the course doable. I don't think I would have been able to complete the course without this support network.
If a student has a strong interest in Chemistry and Applied Math I would recommend the course, but I would not recommend it to all students because it is definitely time and energy intensive.
I would recommend this course for anyone who is interested in the quantitative chemistry aspect and is willing to challenge themselves.

Only if the student is interested in the more mathematical side of chemistry/physics. I was hoping that, like the first semester of Chem 163, this would continue our exploration of chemistry in a more qualitative, contextual way.
I would definitely recommend this course to another Yale student. I enjoyed learning about a variety of chemistry topics in a balanced and quick-paced manner.

I took this course because I placed out of General University Chem and wanted to challenge myself; in terms of the material, I think the course does this successfully and on those grounds I would recommend it. I wouldn't recommend it for anyone who hasn't taken AP chem or who is just taking chem to fulfill premed requirements.

Only if you need to take it. Gen Chem (165) is a far easier alternative, and unless you plan to take P chem, you won't really need any of the concepts covered in this course. 167's precursor (163) is a much better and more useful course overall.

I would recommend this course to a student who has a strong chemistry background and wants to take  a "comprehensive course" that will still enable them to learn a lot of new material and be intellectually stimulated and challenged.
Yes I would recommend it to any freshman loooking to deepen their knowledge of chemistry.

Only if they want to be a chemistry or chemical engineering major. It is a very intense class that requires a lot of work, and is purely inorganic physical chemistry. It is interesting, but not good for an intro chemistry class, in my opinion.

I would only recommend this course to someone who is interested in chemistry, and/or is thinking about majoring in chemical or biological sciences, or engineering. It is a challenging class in every way so in order to succeed, you have to be willing to learn and work hard.
No, definitely take 165 you can. There's literally no purpose to take 167 instead and its not worth the extra difficulty and workload.

Only if you have a genuine interest in chemistry, want to learn more conceptually than mathematically, and don't mind putting in a lot of work and time. A background with chem, calc, and physics would help, as well. CHEM 167 is much harder than CHEM 165 but also much more rewarding when you finish the course.

I would most definitely recommend this course to another student: the amount of material you cover is astounding, and although that sounds intimidating, it is worth taking the course. The material in the course overlaps with CHEM 165, but the depth you go into some topics (and the introduction of new topics entirely) is worth going into if you are interested in chemistry: I would recommend this course in conjunction with CHEM 163, however, since one topic (Materials Chemistry) takes some knowledge learned in CHEM 163 into the lectures (although this topic was not heavily emphasized in CHEM 167, and more emphasized in CHEM 163). Definitely a great class. Also Professor Wang makes some funny jokes, so it livens the atmosphere too.

I would recommend this course under specific circumstances. To people who are already experienced with chemistry or deeply enjoy the subject, this course will feed into your existing interests and could potentially be one of the most interesting chemistry courses you take at Yale. To people who require time spend time to truly understand the material, do not already have an above-average understanding of chemistry, or want to learn things from the ground up, I would not recommend this course. This course moves very rapidly, so any gaps in your understanding will add up. I don't think this course is suitable for people who need an instructor to go into detail about why things work or behave the way they do.

If you're going into chemistry specifically, it probably provides far more insights than chem 165. It's also a LOT more work. Don't take it just because you took chem 163. It is very different, and very math-heavy. Really think about whether you want to take this course.
Yes, this class is wonderful if you have a strong interest in chemistry or learning in general. If this class is only being taken to fulfill a requirement, Chemistry 165 is better.
